author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ah! The tape splice is why I don’t like The Beach Boys

author: Rob Domos
content:
Also think about turnaround times. You work on 15+ songs a day as an ME, you hear aberrant clicks and pops in *nearly every single one of them* 

With asking the person who sent you the files to do it, you spend your whole day emailing and managing files. It takes longer to open gmail than it does to zap the click. 

And think of the logical conclusion of asking the mixing engineer to fix the edit. They don’t have the edit, they have the comp. So then if you extend the logic they have to hit up the producer, and MAYBE the producer has to hit up the recording engineer if you really wanna “get to the source”. It’s like the meme of the producer who didn’t want to use splice because it was cheating and ended up farming sheep to get skin to make his own drumheads. Just do the fucking work. There’s no time to email back and forth about things that can be fixed immediately

author: Josh
content:
So I got a note saying “just make these sound like the first song”. And I ended up spending four hours chasing drum sounds. When I finally reached my wits end I opened the first song’s session and remembered that when he said “I want the drums to sounds like travis barker produced them” I immediately opened splice and just layered in his sample pack for shits and giggles (and because I really don’t like super squashed drums) and they cleared the song immediately. 

TLDR: I chased sounds for four hours because I forgot I did some dumb shit that ended up sounding great lmao.

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

That plus a splice account and ableton and she'll have all the experience and education she needs

author: Jodonny
content: So here's the issue with samples from Splice. I'm not crazy. The downloaded sample's transient sounds completely different than the Splice browser. No fades, no plugins whatsoever. It's not an Ableton thing because it sounds the same in Quicktime.

author: Jodonny
content: I figured it out. Splice uses a MP3 conversion in their browser previews (which creates an artifact before the sample) and then uses a limiter and normalization to keep sample volumes consistent when browsing (which brings up the volume of the artifact).

author: Josh
content: Just keep in mind that suggestions are suggestions. Especially with gear and plugins. I use the stock Cubase dynamic eq more than the fabfilter. I also use the slate Infiniti EQ more than anything else because it’s fantastic. I use Ozone for most of processing because it’s just simple and I learned it really well. Just figure out what you like and what works for you. You can demo all of these things, splice doesn’t rent to own. Just don’t blindly buy $300 plugins because there’s a good choice you won’t use them. (This is also being said to my younger self haha)

author: Slow Hand
content: The Fiery Furnaces did a really neat live album a decade ago where they spliced together all of their live performances into a full album. Now many bands do that already, but they combined multiple takes for each *song.*  They'd take the chorus from Night 1 and splice it onto the second verse of night 4 and then do the outro from Night 7. The cool part was that the recordings, rooms, and audience are drastically different, so you end up with lots of cool sonic shifts on the downbeats of each section in the songs.

author: Josh
content: Also in your splice settings you can switch it over to your external, aaaaand you can do the same with your Dropbox client.

author: Jodonny
content: Has anyone noticed that samples sound different in the Splice app/web browser vs when downloaded? I mainly use Splice for one-off sounds like congas right now, and the transient is wildly different than when downloaded. Tested it out in Quicktime and Ableton w/ no plugins or fades. No Splice Bridge affecting it.

author: Jodonny
content: Splice isn't putting limiting and normalization on the downloaded files, you're hearing what the producer intended there. The browser is crazy loud because they've normalized all the samples up to near 0db to be as loud as possible. Try using the "normalization" feature in Logic's output and it'll make sense.

author: Jodonny
content: But my point is every pack/producer's samples are different, it's not just a Splice thing (and I'm here talking about how I don't want to use Splice...). Some people like that clipped sound. If you don't like it you can find other packs.

author: LAPhill
content:
Not exactly my point. AI is going to take awhile to replace various aspects of what we do. So creators can drive where THEY see value, in hopes of steering the tech. If everyone here hates timing drums, and an AI can come along to do it while maintaining groove and feel, perfect transients, etc., that saves time and is worth something.

Whether or not that's more valuable to the tech company than offering 50,000 bedroom producers the tools to make "pro-sounding" beats easier than with Splice.... probably not.

I did end up using audiomovers today, and it sounded great - but dang they really try to get you with the year payment only options.
